awd_titl_txt: RUI: Sensitive Searches for Compact Binary Coalescence in LIGO Data
awd_abstract_narration:
This project continues the development and use of advanced software algorithms to search for gravitational waves - ripples in spacetime predicted by Einstein's theory of gravity - in data from the Advanced Laser Interferometer Gravitational-Wave Observatory (LIGO). These are a predicted signature of some of the most energetic events in the universe, including neutron stars and black holes that orbit one another and spiral inwards and collide.  The detection of gravitational waves from such collisions will allow a direct confirmation of this prediction of Einstein's theory, and will also allow measurement of the properties of the neutron stars or black holes whose collision generated the waves.  Such properties are often difficult to measure indirectly through present observations with telescopes and satellites.  The broader impacts of this proposal will include the training of undergraduate students in the nascent field of gravitational wave astronomy, and dissemination of the first results of that field to the broader public through short videos and public talks.
 
The specific problem this proposal will address is the tuning and deployment of an offline, matched-filter search for compact binary coalescing sources for non-spinning and aligned-spin systems, and the development and testing of a search for precessing spin systems.  This will be done using the PyCBC pipeline toolkit of which the PI is a developer, and the tuning studies and investigation of precessing searches will each test the detection sensitivity of their respective searches on Mock Data Challenge (MDC) data collected from earlier LIGO running and engineering runs.  These detection sensitivity studies will in turn be used to decide on tuning choices, and for precessing searches, whether overall detection efficiency is improved by searching over a precessing waveform template parameter space.  Broader impacts will be achieved by involving undergraduates in this research both locally at ACU, and by traveling to the Albert Einstein Institute in Hannover, Germany. Additionally, public outreach will continue the sequence of short, educational videos that the PI and his students have already made on relativity.

por.por_cntn:
On September 14, 2015, the Laser Interferometer Gravitational-Wave Obnservatory (LIGO) witnessed the merger of two black holes at a distance of over a billion light years. This confirmed a key prediction of Einstein's theory of gravity, and was also the first time two black holes had been observed in orbit around each other (previously, only isolated black holes had been observed). Over the rest of its first and second observing runs, LIGO and partner observatory Virgo would observe a total of ten such black hole mergers. Additionally, on August 17, 2017, LIGO and Virgo observed two neutron stars merging, an event that was also seen by ground and space based telescopes. This joint observation confirmed a key hypothesis for how some of a certain class of astronomical events---gamma-ray bursts---are generated, and allowed comparison among detailed models of what neutron stars are like. These discoveries are harbingers of much more knowledge about the universe that will come as more and more such observations are made, with ever more sensitive detectors.

Discoveries such as these require large teams of scientists working together; the work in this award was to analyze the data produced by these detectors, to identify the signals of these mergers of black holes and neutron stars.  As sensitive as the detectors are, such signals are still quite weak, and it is unknown when and where they will occur.  Thus, sophisticated software is needed to look through all of the data, search for the signals theory predicts, and measure objectively how likely it is that anything found could have been caused by noise, rather than a real astronomical event. Such searches require large amounts of computation as well as expertise to deploy and run, but without them, none of these observations could have been made.  This award supported part of the team that worked on one of the pieces of software used on this analysis, both to create and improve the software itself, and also to search the data with it, and make those discoveries.

As part of this project, two undergraduates were able to gain hands-on experience in cutting-edge research and software development. Through this award, the excitement of the  ground-breaking discoveries above was communicated to such diverse groups as world experts in computing, the largest gathering of undergraduate physics majors in the world, and students at a local elementary school. The software developed (called PyCBC) is available at no cost to anyone on the web, and includes advanced techniques to leverage both traditional computers and graphics cards. Anyone may download it to analyze gravitational-wave data, or use its capabilities (extending it if needed) on other computationally intensive problems.
